books.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:1
verses.text: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III: Chapter I.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:2
verses.text: We are taught by David and Solomon how to take counsel with our own heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:3
verses.text: Scipio is not to be accounted prime author of the saying which is ascribed to him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:4
verses.text: The writer proves what glorious things the holy prophets accomplished in their time of quiet, and shows, by examples of their and others' leisure moments, that a just man is never alone in trouble.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:6
verses.text: The prophet David taught us that we should go about in our heart as though in a large house; that we should hold converse with it as with some trusty companion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:7
verses.text: He spoke to himself, and conversed with himself, as these words show: "I said, I will take heed to my ways".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:8
verses.text: Solomon his son also said: "Drink water out of thine own vessels, and out of the springs of thy wells; " that is: use thine own counsel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:9
verses.text: For: "Counsel in the heart of a man is as deep waters".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:10
verses.text: "Let no stranger," it says, "share it with thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:11
verses.text: Let the fountain of thy water be thine own, and rejoice with thy wife who is thine from thy youth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:12
verses.text: Let the loving hind and pleasant doe converse with thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:13
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:14
verses.text: Scipio, therefore, was not the first to know that he was not alone when he was alone, or that he was least at leisure when he was at leisure.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:15
verses.text: For Moses knew it before him, who, when silent, was crying out; who, when he stood at ease, was fighting, nay, not merely fighting but triumphing over enemies whom he had not come near.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:16
verses.text: So much was he at ease, that others held up his hands; yet he was no less active than others, for he with his hands at ease was overcoming the enemy, whom they that were in the battle could not conquer.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:17
verses.text: Thus Moses in his silence spoke, and in his ease laboured hard.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:18
verses.text: And were his labours greater than his times of quiet, who, being in the mount for forty days, received the whole law? And in that solitude there was One not far away to speak with him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:19
verses.text: Whence also David says: "I will hear what the Lord God will say within me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:20
verses.text: How much greater a thing is it for God to speak with any one, than for a man to speak with himself!  3.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:21
verses.text: The apostles passed by and their shadows cured the sick.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:22
verses.text: Their garments were touched and health was granted.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:23
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:24
verses.text: Elijah spoke the word, and the rain ceased and fell not on the earth for three years and six months.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:25
verses.text: Again he spoke, and the barrel of meal failed not, and the cruse of oil wasted not the whole time of that long famine.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:26
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:27
verses.text: But—as many delight in warfare—which is the most glorious, to bring a battle to an end by the strength of a great army, or, by merits before God alone? Elisha rested in one place while the king of Syria waged a great war against the people of our fathers, and was adding to its terrors by various treacherous plans, and was endeavouring to catch them in an ambush.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:28
verses.text: But the prophet found out all their preparations, and being by the grace of God present everywhere in mental vigour, he told the thoughts of their enemies to his countrymen, and warned them of what places to beware.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:29
verses.text: And when this was known to the king of Syria, he sent an army and shut in the prophet.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:30
verses.text: Elisha prayed and caused all of them to be struck with blindness, and made those who had come to besiege him enter Samaria as captives.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:31
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:32
verses.text: Let us compare this leisure of his with that of others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:33
verses.text: Other men for the sake of rest are wont to withdraw their minds from business, and to retire from the company and companionship of men; to seek the retirement of the country or the solitude of the fields, or in the city to give their minds a rest and to enjoy peace and quietness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:34
verses.text: But Elisha was ever active.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:35
verses.text: In solitude he divided Jordan on passing over it, so that the lower part flowed down, whilst the upper returned to its source.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:36
verses.text: On Carmel he promises the woman, who so far had had no child, that a son now unhoped for should be born to her.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:37
verses.text: He raises the dead to life, he corrects the bitterness of the food, and makes it to be sweet by mixing meal with it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:38
verses.text: Having distributed ten loaves to the people for food, he gathered up the fragments that were left after they had been filled.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:39
verses.text: He makes the iron head of the axe, which had fallen off and was sunk deep in the river Jordan, to swim by putting the wooden handle in the water.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:40
verses.text: He changes leprosy for cleanness, drought for rain, famine for plenty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:41
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:42
verses.text: When can the upright man be alone, since he is always with God? When is he left forsaken who is never separated from Christ? "Who," it says, "shall separate us from the love of Christ? I am confident that neither death nor life nor angel shall do so".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:43
verses.text: And when can he be deprived of his labour who never can be deprived of his merits, wherein his labour receives its crown? By what places is he limited to whom the whole world of riches is a possession? By what judgment is he confined who is never blamed by any one? For he is "as unknown yet well known, as dying and behold he lives, as sorrowful yet always rejoicing, as poor yet making many rich, as having nothing and yet possessing all things".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:44
verses.text: For the upright man regards nothing but what is consistent and virtuous.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 1:45
verses.text: And so although he seems poor to another, he is rich to himself, for his worth is taken not at the value of the things which are temporal, but of the things which are eternal.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:2
verses.text: The discussions among philosophers about the comparison between what is virtuous and what is useful have nothing to do with Christians.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:3
verses.text: For with them nothing is useful which is not just.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:4
verses.text: What are the duties of perfection, and what are ordinary duties? The same words often suit different things in different ways.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:5
verses.text: Lastly, a just man never seeks his own advantage at the cost of another's disadvantage, but rather is always on the lookout for what is useful to others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:6
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:7
verses.text: As we have already spoken about the two former subjects, wherein we discussed what is virtuous and what is useful, there follows now the question whether we ought to compare what is virtuous and useful together, and to ask which we must follow.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:8
verses.text: For, as we have already discussed the matter as to whether a thing is virtuous or wicked, and in another place whether it is useful or useless, so here some think we ought to find out whether a thing is virtuous or useful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:9
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:10
verses.text: I am induced to do this, lest I should seem to be allowing that these two are mutually opposed to one another, when I have already shown them to be one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:11
verses.text: For I said that nothing can be virtuous but what is useful, and nothing can be useful but what is virtuous.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:12
verses.text: For we do not follow the wisdom of the flesh, whereby the usefulness that consists in an abundance of money is held to be of most value, but we follow that wisdom which is of God, whereby  those things which are greatly valued in this world are counted but as loss.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:13
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:14
verses.text: For this χατόρθωμα, which is duty carried out entirely and in perfection, starts from the true source of virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:15
verses.text: On this follows another, or ordinary duty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:16
verses.text: This shows by its name that no hard or extraordinary practice of virtue is involved, for it can be common to very many.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:17
verses.text: The desire to save money is the usual practice with many.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:18
verses.text: To enjoy a well-prepared banquet and a pleasant meal is a general habit; but to fast or to use self-restraint is the practice of but few, and not to be desirous of another's goods is a virtue rarely found.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:19
verses.text: On the other hand, to wish to deprive another of his property—and not to be content with one's due—here one will find many to keep company with one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:20
verses.text: Those (the philosopher would say) are primary duties—these ordinary.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:21
verses.text: The primary are found but with few, the ordinary with the many.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:22
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:23
verses.text: Again, the same words often have a different meaning.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:24
verses.text: For instance, we call God good and a man good; but it bears in each case quite a different meaning.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:25
verses.text: We call God just in one sense, man in another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:26
verses.text: So, too, there is a difference in meaning when we call God wise and a man wise.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:27
verses.text: This we are taught in the Gospel: "Be ye perfect even as your Father Who is in heaven is perfect".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:28
verses.text: I read again that Paul was perfect and yet not perfect.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:29
verses.text: For when he said: "Not as though I had already attained, either were already perfect; but I follow after, if that I may apprehend it".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:30
verses.text: Immediately he added: "We, then, that are perfect".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:31
verses.text: There is a twofold form of perfection, the one having but ordinary, the other the highest worth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:32
verses.text: The one availing here, the other hereafter.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:33
verses.text: The one in accordance with human powers, the other with the perfection of the world to come.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:34
verses.text: But God is just through all, wise above all, perfect in all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:35
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:36
verses.text: There is also diversity even among men themselves.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:37
verses.text: Daniel, of whom it was said: "Who is wiser than Daniel?" was wise in a different sense to what others are.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:38
verses.text: The same may be said of Solomon, who was filled with wisdom, above all the wisdom of the ancients, and more than all the wise men of Egypt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:39
verses.text: To be wise as men are in general is quite a different thing to being really wise.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:40
verses.text: He who is ordinarily wise is wise for temporal matters, is wise for himself, so as to deprive another of something and get it for himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:41
verses.text: He who is really wise does not know how to regard his own advantage, but looks with all his desire to that which is eternal, and to that which is seemly and virtuous, seeking not what is useful for himself, but for all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:42
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:43
verses.text: Let this, then, be our rule, so that we may never go wrong between two things, one virtuous, the other useful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:44
verses.text: The upright man must never think of depriving another of anything, nor must he ever wish to increase his own advantage to the disadvantage of another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:45
verses.text: This rule the Apostle gives thee, saying: "All things are lawful, but all things are not expedient; all things are lawful, but all things edify not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:46
verses.text: Let no man seek his own, but each one another's".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:47
verses.text: That is: Let no man seek his own advantage, but another's; let no man seek his own honour, but another's.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:48
verses.text: Wherefore he says in another place: "Let each esteem other better than themselves, looking not each one to his own things, but to the things of others".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:49
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:50
verses.text: And let no one seek his own favour or his own praise, but another's.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:51
verses.text: This we can plainly see declared in the book of Proverbs, where the Holy Spirit says through Solomon: "My son, if thou be wise, be wise for thyself and thy neighbours; but if thou turn out evil, thou alone shalt bear it".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 2:52
verses.text: The wise man gives counsel to others, as the upright man does, and shares with him in wearing the form of either virtue.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:2
verses.text: The rule given about not seeking one's own gain is established, first by the examples of Christ, next by the meaning of the word, and lastly by the very form and uses of our limbs.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:3
verses.text: Wherefore the writer shows what a crime it is to deprive another of what is useful, since the law of nature as well as the divine law is broken by such wickedness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:4
verses.text: Further, by its means we also lose that gift which makes us superior to other living creatures; and lastly, through it civil laws are abused and treated with the greatest contempt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:6
verses.text: If, then, any one wishes to please all, he must strive in everything to do, not what is useful for himself, but what is useful for many, as also Paul strove to do.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:7
verses.text: For this is "to be conformed to the image of Christ," namely, when one does not strive for what is another's, and does not deprive another of something so as to gain it for  oneself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:8
verses.text: For Christ our Lord, though He was in the form of God, emptied Himself so as to take on Himself the form of man, which He wished to enrich with the virtue of His works.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:9
verses.text: Wilt thou, then, spoil him whom Christ has put on? Wilt thou strip him whom Christ has clothed? For this is what thou art doing when thou dost attempt to increase thine own advantage at another's loss.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:11
verses.text: Think, O man, from whence thou hast received thy name—even from the earth, which takes nothing from any one, but gives freely to all, and supplies varied produce for the use of all living things.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:12
verses.text: Hence humanity is called a particular and innate virtue in man, for it assists its partner.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:13
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:14
verses.text: The very form of thy body and the uses of thy limbs teach thee this.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:15
verses.text: Can one limb claim the duties of another? Can the eye claim for itself the duties of the ear; or the mouth the duties of the eye; or the hand the service of the feet; or the feet that of the hands? Nay, the hands themselves, both left and right, have different duties to do, so that if one were to change the use of either, one would act contrary to nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:16
verses.text: We should have to lay aside the whole man before we could change the service of the various members: as if, for instance, we were to try to take food with the left hand, or to perform the duties of the left hand with the right, so as to remove the remains of food—unless, of course, need demanded it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:17
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:18
verses.text: Imagine for a moment, and give to the eye the power to withdraw the understanding from the head, the sense of hearing from the ears, the power of thought from the mind, the sense of smell from the nose, the sense of taste from the mouth, and then to assume them itself, would it not at once destroy the whole order of nature? Wherefore the Apostle says well: "If the whole body were an eye, where were the hearing? If the whole were hearing, where were the smelling?" So, then, we are all one body, though with many members, all necessary to the body.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:19
verses.text: For no one member can say of another: "I have no need of thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:20
verses.text: For those members which seem to be more feeble are much more necessary and require greater care and attention.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:21
verses.text: And if one member suffers, all the members suffer with it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:22
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:23
verses.text: So we see how grave a matter it is to deprive another, with whom we ought rather to suffer, of anything, or to act unfairly or injuriously towards one to whom we ought to give a share in our services.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:24
verses.text: This is a true law of nature, which binds us to show all kindly feeling, so that we should all of us in turn help one another, as parts of one body, and should never think of depriving another of anything, seeing it is against the law of nature even to abstain from giving help.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:25
verses.text: We are born in such a way that limb combines with limb, and one works with another, and all assist each other in mutual service.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:26
verses.text: But if one fails in its duty, the rest are hindered.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:27
verses.text: If, for instance, the hand tears out the eye, has it not hindered the use of its work? If it were to wound the foot, how many actions would it not prevent? But how much worse is it for the whole man to be drawn aside from his duty than for one of the members only! If the whole body is injured in one member, so also is the whole community of the human race disturbed in one man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:28
verses.text: The nature of mankind is injured, as also is the society of the holy Church, which rises into one united body, bound together in oneness of faith and love.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:29
verses.text: Christ the Lord, also, Who died for all, will grieve that the price of His blood was paid in vain.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:30
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:31
verses.text: Why, the very law of the Lord teaches us that this rule must be observed, so that we may never deprive another of anything for the sake of our own advantage.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:32
verses.text: For it says: "Remove not the bounds which thy fathers have set".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:33
verses.text: It bids a neighbour's ox to be brought back if found wandering.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:34
verses.text: It orders a thief to be put to death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:35
verses.text: It forbids the labourer to be deprived of his hire, and orders money to be returned without usury.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:36
verses.text: It is a mark of kindly feeling to help him who has nothing, but it is a sign of a hard nature to extort more than one has given.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:37
verses.text: If a man has need of thy assistance because he has not enough of his own wherewith to repay a debt, is it not a wicked thing to demand under the guise of kindly feeling a larger sum from him who has not the means to pay off a less amount? Thou dost but free him from debt to another, to bring him under thy own hand; and thou callest that human kindliness which is but a further wickedness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:38
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:39
verses.text: It is in this very matter that we stand before all other living creatures, for they do not understand how to do good.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:40
verses.text: Wild beasts snatch away, men share with others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:41
verses.text: Wherefore the Psalmist says: "The righteous showeth mercy and giveth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:42
verses.text: There are some, however, to whom the wild beasts do good.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:43
verses.text: They feed their young with what they get, and the birds satisfy their brood with food; but to men alone has it been given to feed all as though they were their own.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:44
verses.text: That is so in accordance with the claims of nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:45
verses.text: And if it is not lawful to refuse to give, how is it lawful to deprive another? And do not our very laws teach us the same? They order those things which have been taken from others with injury to their persons or property to be restored with additional recompense; so as to check the thief from stealing by the penalty, and by the fine to recall him from his ways.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:46
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:47
verses.text: Suppose, however, that some one did not fear the penalty, or laughed at the fine, would that make it a worthy thing to deprive another of his own? That would be a mean vice and suited only to the lowest of the low.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:48
verses.text: So contrary to nature is it, that while want might seem to drive one to it, yet nature could never urge it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:49
verses.text: And yet we find secret theft among slaves, open robbery among the rich.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:50
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:51
verses.text: But what so contrary to nature as to injure another for our own benefit? The natural feelings of our own hearts urge us to keep on the watch for all, to undergo trouble, to do work for all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:52
verses.text: It is considered also a glorious thing for each one at risk to himself to seek the quiet of all, and to think it far more thankworthy to have saved his country from destruction than to have kept danger from himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 3:53
verses.text: We must think it a far more noble thing to labour for our country than to pass a quiet life at ease in the full enjoyment of leisure.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:2
verses.text: As it has been shown that he who injures another for the sake of his own advantage will undergo terrible punishment at the hand of his own conscience, it is referred that nothing is useful to one which is not in the same way useful to all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:3
verses.text: Thus there is no place among Christians for the question propounded by the philosophers about two shipwrecked persons, for they must show love and humility to all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:5
verses.text: Hence we infer that a man who guides himself according to the ruling of nature, so as to be obedient to her, can never injure another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:6
verses.text: If he injures another, he violates nature, nor will he think that what he has gained is so much an advantage as a disadvantage.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:7
verses.text: And what punishment is worse than the wounds of the conscience within? What judgment harder than that of our hearts, whereby each one stands convicted and accuses himself of the injury that he has wrongfully done against his brother? This the Scriptures speak of very plainly, saying: "Out of the mouth of fools there is a rod for wrong-doing".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:8
verses.text: Folly, then, is condemned because it causes wrong-doing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:9
verses.text: Ought we not rather to avoid this, than death, or loss, or want, or exile, or sickness? Who would not think some blemish of body or loss of inheritance far less than some blemish of soul or loss of reputation?  25.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:10
verses.text: It is clear, then, that all must consider and hold that the advantage of the individual is the same as that of all, and that nothing must be considered advantageous except what is for the general good.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:11
verses.text: For how can one be benefited alone? That which is useless to all is harmful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:12
verses.text: I certainly cannot think that he who is useless to all can be of use to himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:13
verses.text: For if there is one law of nature for all, there is also one state of usefulness for all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:14
verses.text: And we are bound by the law of nature to act for the good of all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:15
verses.text: It is not, therefore, right for him who wishes the interests of another to be considered according to nature, to injure him against the law of nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:16
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:17
verses.text: For if those who run in a race are, as one hears, instructed and warned each one to win the race by swiftness of foot and not by any foul play, and to hasten on to victory by running as hard as they can, but not to dare to trip up another or push him aside with their hand, how much more in the course of this life ought the victory to be won by us, without falseness to another and cheating?  27.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:18
verses.text: Some ask whether a wise man ought in case of a shipwreck to take away a plank from an ignorant sailor? Although it seems better for the common good that a wise man rather than a fool should escape from shipwreck, yet I do not think that a Christian, a just and a wise man, ought to save his own life by the death of another; just as when he meets with an armed robber he cannot return his blows, lest in defending his life he should stain his love toward his neighbour.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:19
verses.text: The verdict on this is plain and clear in the books of the Gospel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:20
verses.text: "Put up thy sword, for every one that taketh the sword shall perish with the sword".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:21
verses.text: What robber is more hateful than the persecutor who came to kill Christ? But Christ would  not be defended from the wounds of the persecutor, for He willed to heal all by His wounds.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:22
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:23
verses.text: Why dost thou consider thyself greater than another, when a Christian man ought to put others before himself, to claim nothing for himself, usurp no honours, claim no reward for his merits? Why, next, art thou not wont to bear thy own troubles rather than to destroy another's advantage? For what is so contrary to nature as not to be content with what one has or to seek what is another's, and to try to get it in shameful ways.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:24
verses.text: For if a virtuous life is in accordance with nature—for God made all things very good—then shameful living must be opposed to it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 4:25
verses.text: A virtuous and a shameful life cannot go together, since they are absolutely severed by the law of nature.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:2
verses.text: The upright does nothing that is contrary to duty, even though there is a hope of keeping it secret.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:3
verses.text: To point this out the tale about the ring of Gyges was invented by the philosophers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:4
verses.text: Exposing this, he brings forward known and true examples from the life of David and John the Baptist.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:6
verses.text: To lay down here already the result of our discussion, as though we had already ended it, we declare it a fixed rule, that we must never aim at anything but what is virtuous.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:7
verses.text: The wise man does nothing but what can be done openly and without falseness, nor does he do anything whereby he may involve himself in any wrong-doing, even where he may escape notice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:8
verses.text: For he is guilty in his own eyes, before being so in the eyes of others; and the publicity of his crime does not bring him more shame than his own consciousness of it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:9
verses.text: This we can show, not by the made-up stories which philosophers use, but from the true examples of good men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:11
verses.text: I need not, therefore, imagine a great chasm in the earth, which had been loosened by heavy rains, and had afterwards burst asunder, as Plato does.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:12
verses.text: For he makes Gyges descend into that chasm, and to meet there that iron horse of the fable that had doors in its sides.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:13
verses.text: When these doors were opened, he found a gold ring on the finger of a dead man, whose corpse lay there lifeless.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:14
verses.text: He desiring the gold took away the ring.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:15
verses.text: But when he returned to the king's shepherds, to whose number he belonged, by chance having turned the stone inwards towards the palms of his hands, he saw all, yet was seen by none.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:16
verses.text: Then when he turned the ring to its proper position, he was again seen by all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:17
verses.text: On becoming conscious of this strange power, by the use of the ring he committed adultery with the queen, killed the king, and took possession of the kingdom after slaying all the rest, who he thought should be put to death, so that they might be no hindrance to him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:18
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:19
verses.text: Give, says Plato, this ring to a wise man, that when he commits a fault he may by its help remain unnoticed; yet he will be none the more free from the stain of sin than if he could not be hid.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:20
verses.text: The hiding-place of the wise lies not in the hope of impunity but in his own innocency.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:21
verses.text: Lastly, the law is not laid down for the just but for the unjust.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:22
verses.text: For the just has within himself the law of his mind, and a rule of equity and justice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:23
verses.text: Thus he is not recalled from sin by fear of punishment, but by the rule of a virtuous life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:24
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:25
verses.text: Therefore, to return to our subject, I will now bring forward, not false examples for true, but true examples in place of false.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:26
verses.text: For why need I imagine a chasm in the earth, and an iron horse and a gold ring found on the fingers of a dead man; and say that such was the power of this ring, that he who wore it could appear at his own will, but if he did not wish to be seen, he could remove himself out of the sight of those who stood by, so as to seem to be away.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:27
verses.text: This story, of course, is meant to answer the question whether a wise man, on getting the opportunity of using that ring so as to be able to hide his crimes, and to obtain a kingdom,—whether, I say, a wise man would be unwilling to sin and would consider the stain of sin far worse than the pains of punishment, or whether he would use it for doing wickedness in the hope of not being found out? Why, I say, should I need the pretence of a ring, when I can show from what has been done that a wise man, on seeing he would not only be undetected in his sin, but would also gain a kingdom if he gave way to it, and who, on the other hand, noted danger to his own safety if he did not commit the crime, yet chose to risk his own safety so as to be free from crime, rather than to commit the crime and so gain the kingdom.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:28
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:29
verses.text: When David fled from the face of King Saul, because the king was seeking him in the desert with three thousand chosen men  to put him to death, he entered the king's camp and found him sleeping.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:30
verses.text: There he not only did him no injury, but actually guarded him from being slain by any who had entered with him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:31
verses.text: For when Abishai said to him: "The Lord hath delivered thine enemy into thine hand this day, now therefore I will slay him," he answered: "Destroy him not, for who can stretch forth his hand against the Lord's anointed, and be guiltless?" And he added: "As the Lord liveth, unless the Lord shall smite him, or his day shall come to die, or he shall die in battle, and it be laid to me, the Lord forbid that I should stretch out my hand against the Lord's anointed".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:32
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:33
verses.text: Therefore he did not suffer him to be slain, but removed only his spear, which stood by his head, and his cruse of water.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:34
verses.text: Then, whilst all were sleeping, he left the camp and went across to the top of the hill, and began to reproach the royal attendants, and especially their general Abner, for not keeping faithful watch over their lord and king.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:35
verses.text: Next, he showed them where the king's spear and cruse were which had stood at his head.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:36
verses.text: And when the king called to him, he restored the spear, and said: "The Lord render to every man his righteousness and faithfulness, for the Lord delivered thee into my hand, but I would not avenge myself on the Lord's anointed".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:37
verses.text: Even whilst he said this, he feared his plots and fled, changing his place in exile.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:38
verses.text: However, he never put safety before innocency, seeing that when a second opportunity was given him of killing the king, he would not use the chance that came to him, and which put in his reach certain safety instead of fear, and a kingdom instead of exile.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:39
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:40
verses.text: Where was the use of the ring in John's case, who would not have been put to death by Herod if he had kept silence? He could have kept silence before him so as to be both seen and yet not killed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:41
verses.text: But because he not only could not endure to sin himself to protect his own safety, but could not bear and endure even another's sin, he brought about the cause of his own death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:42
verses.text: Certainly none can deny that he might have kept silence, who in the case of Gyges deny that he could have remained invisible by the help of the ring.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:43
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:44
verses.text: But although that fable has not the force of truth, yet it has this much to go upon, that if an upright man could hide himself, yet he would avoid sin just as though he could not conceal himself; and that he would not hide his person by putting on a ring, but his life by putting on Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:45
verses.text: As the Apostle says: "Our life is hid with Christ in God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:46
verses.text: Let, then, no one here strive to shine, let none show pride, let none boast.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:47
verses.text: Christ willed not to be known here, He would not that His Name should be preached in the Gospel whilst He lived on earth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:48
verses.text: He came to lie hid from this world.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:49
verses.text: Let us therefore likewise hide our life after the example of Christ, let us shun boastfulness, let us not desire to be made known.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:50
verses.text: It is better to live here in humility, and there in glory.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 5:51
verses.text: "When Christ," it says, "shall appear, then shall we also appear with Him in glory".

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:2
verses.text: We ought not to allow the idea of profit to get hold of us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:3
verses.text: What excuses they make who get their gains by selling corn, and what answer ought to be made to them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:4
verses.text: In connection with this certain parables from the Gospels and some of the sayings of Solomon are set before our eyes.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:6
verses.text: Let not, therefore, expediency get the better of virtue, but virtue of expediency.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:7
verses.text: By expediency here I mean what is accounted so by people generally.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:8
verses.text: Let love of money be destroyed, let lust die.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:9
verses.text: The holy man says that he has never been engaged in business.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:10
verses.text: For to get an increase in price is a sign not of simplicity but of cunning.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:11
verses.text: Elsewhere it says: "He that seeketh a high price for his corn is cursed among the people".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:12
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:13
verses.text: Plain and definite is the statement, leaving no room for debate, such as a disputatious kind of speaking is wont to give, when one maintains that agriculture is considered praiseworthy by all; that the fruits of the earth are easily grown; that the more a man has sown, the greater will be his meed of praise; further, that the richer returns of his active labours are not gained by fraud, and that carelessness and disregard for an uncultivated soil are wont to be blamed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:14
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:15
verses.text: I have ploughed, he says, carefully.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:16
verses.text: I have sown freely.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:17
verses.text: I have tilled actively.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:18
verses.text: I have gathered good increase.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:19
verses.text: I have stored it anxiously, saved it faithfully, and guarded it with care.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:20
verses.text: Now in a time of famine I  sell it, and come to the help of the hungry.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:21
verses.text: I sell my own corn, not another's.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:22
verses.text: And for no more than others, nay, even at a less price.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:23
verses.text: What fraud is there here, when many would come to great danger if they had nothing to buy? Is industry to be made a crime? Or diligence to be blamed? Or foresight to be abused? Perhaps he may even say: Joseph collected corn in a time of abundance, and sold it when it was dear.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:24
verses.text: Is any one forced to buy it at too dear a price? Is force employed against the buyer? The opportunity to buy is afforded to all, injury is inflicted on none.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:25
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:26
verses.text: When this has been said, and one man's ideas have carried him so far, another rises and says: Agriculture is good indeed, for it supplies fruits for all, and by simple industry adds to the richness of the earth without any cheating or fraud.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:27
verses.text: If there is any error, the loss is the greater, for the better a man sows, the better he will reap.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:28
verses.text: If he has sown the pure grain of wheat, he gathers a purer and cleaner harvest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:29
verses.text: The fruitful earth returns what she has received in manifold measure.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:30
verses.text: A good field returns its produce with interest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:31
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:32
verses.text: Thou must expect payment for thy labour from the crops of the fruitful land, and must hope for a just return from the fruitfulness of the rich earth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:33
verses.text: Why dost thou use the industry of nature and make a cheat of it? Why dost thou grudge for the use of men what is grown for all? Why lessen the abundance for the people? Why make want thy aim? Why make the poor long for a barren season? For when they do not feel the benefits of a fruitful season, because thou art putting up the price, and art storing up the corn, they would far rather that nothing should be produced, than that thou shouldst do business at the expense of other people's hunger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:34
verses.text: Thou makest much of the want of corn, the small supply of food.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:35
verses.text: Thou groanest over the rich crops of the soil; thou mournest the general plenty, and bewailest the garners full of corn; thou art on the lookout to see when the crop is poor and the harvest fails.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:36
verses.text: Thou rejoicest that a curse has smiled upon thy wishes, so that none should have their produce.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:37
verses.text: Then thou rejoicest that thy harvest has come.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:38
verses.text: Then thou collectest wealth from the misery of all, and callest this industry and diligence, when it is but cunning shrewdness and an adroit trick of the trade.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:39
verses.text: Thou callest it a remedy, when it is but a wicked contrivance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:40
verses.text: Shall I call this robbery or only gain? These opportunities are seized as though seasons for plunder, wherein, like some cruel waylayer, thou mayest fall upon the stomachs of men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:41
verses.text: The price rises higher as though by the mere addition of interest, but the danger to life is increased too.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:42
verses.text: For then the interest of the stored-up crops grows higher.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:43
verses.text: As a usurer thou hidest up thy corn, as a seller thou puttest it up for auction.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:44
verses.text: Why dost thou wish evil to all, because the famine will grow worse, as though no corn should be left, as though a more unfruitful year should follow? Thy gain is the public loss.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:45
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:46
verses.text: Holy Joseph opened the garners to all; he did not shut them up.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:47
verses.text: He did not try to get the full price of the year's produce, but assigned it for a yearly payment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:48
verses.text: He took nothing for himself, but, so far as famine could be checked for the future, he made his arrangements with careful foresight.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:49
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:50
verses.text: Thou hast read how the Lord Jesus in the Gospel speaks of that corn-dealer who was looking out for a high price, whose possessions brought him in rich fruits, but who, as though still in need, said: "What shall I do? I have no room where to bestow my goods.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:51
verses.text: I will pull down my barns and build greater," though he could not know whether in the following night his soul would not be demanded of him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:52
verses.text: He knew not what to do, he seemed to be in doubt, just as though he were in want of food.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:53
verses.text: His barns could not take in the year's supply, and yet he thought he was in need.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:54
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:55
verses.text: Rightly, therefore, Solomon says: "He that withholdeth corn shall leave it for the nations," not for his heirs, for the gains of avarice have nothing to do with the rights of succession.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:56
verses.text: That which is not rightfully got together is scattered as though by a wind by outsiders that seize it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:57
verses.text: And he added: "He who graspeth at the year's produce is cursed among the people, but blessing shall be his that imparteth it".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:58
verses.text: Thou seest, then, what is said of him who distributes the corn, but not of him that seeks for a high price.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 6:59
verses.text: True expediency does not therefore exist where virtue loses more than expediency gains.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:2
verses.text: Strangers must never be expelled the city in a time of famine.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:3
verses.text: In this matter the noble advice of a Christian sage is adduced, in contrast to which the shameful deed committed at Rome is given.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:4
verses.text: By comparing the two it is shown that the former is combined with what is virtuous and useful, but the latter with neither.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:6
verses.text: But they, too, who would forbid the city to strangers cannot have our approval.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:7
verses.text: They would expel them at the very time when they ought to help, and separate them from the trade of their common parent.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:8
verses.text: They would refuse them a share in the produce meant for all, and avert the intercourse that has already begun; and they are unwilling, in a time of necessity, to give those with whom they have enjoyed their rights in common, a share in what they themselves have.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:9
verses.text: Beasts do not drive out beasts, yet man shuts out man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:10
verses.text: Wild beasts and animals consider food which the earth supplies to be common to all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:11
verses.text: They all give assistance to those like themselves; and man, who ought to think nothing human foreign to himself, fights against his own.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:12
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:13
verses.text: How much better did he act who, having already reached an advanced age, when the city was suffering from famine, and, as is common in such cases, the people demanded that strangers should be forbidden the city, having the office of the prefectship of the city, which is higher than the rest, called together the officials and richer men, and demanded that they should take counsel for the public welfare.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:14
verses.text: He said that it was as cruel a thing for the strangers to be expelled as for one man to be cast off by another, and to be refused food when dying.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:15
verses.text: We do not allow our dogs to come to our table and leave them unfed, yet we shut out a man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:16
verses.text: How unprofitable, again, it is for the world that so many people perish, whom some deadly plague carries off.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:17
verses.text: How unprofitable for their city that so large a number should perish, who were wont to be helpful either in paying contributions or in carrying on business.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:18
verses.text: Another's hunger is profitable to no man, nor to put off the day of help as long as possible and to do nothing to check the want.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:19
verses.text: Nay more, when so many of the cultivators of the soil are gone, when so many labourers are dying, the corn supplies will fail for the future.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:20
verses.text: Shall we then expel those who are wont to supply us with food, are we unwilling to feed in a time of need those who have fed us all along? How great is the assistance which they supply even at this time.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:21
verses.text: "Not by bread alone does man live".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:22
verses.text: They are even our own family; many of them even are our own kindred.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:23
verses.text: Let us make some return for what we have received.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:24
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:25
verses.text: But perhaps we fear that want may increase.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:26
verses.text: First of all, I answer, mercy never fails, but always finds means of help.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:27
verses.text: Next, let us make up for the corn supplies which are to be granted to them, by a subscription.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:28
verses.text: Let us put that right with our gold.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:29
verses.text: And, again, must we not buy other cultivators of the soil if we lose these? How much cheaper is it to feed than to buy a working-man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:30
verses.text: Where, too, can one obtain, where find a man to take the place of the former? And suppose one finds him, do not forget that, with an ignorant man used to different ways, one may fill up the place in point of numbers, but not as regards the work to be done.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:31
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:32
verses.text: Why need I say more? When the money was supplied corn was brought in.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:33
verses.text: So the city's abundance was not diminished, and yet assistance was given to the strangers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:34
verses.text: What praise this act won that holy man from God! What glory among men! He, indeed, had won an honoured name, who, pointing to the people of a whole province, could truly say to the emperor: All these I have preserved for thee; these live owing to the kindness of the senate; these thy council has snatched from death!  49.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:35
verses.text: How much more expedient was this than that which was done lately at Rome.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:36
verses.text: There from that widely extended city were those expelled who had already passed most of their life in it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:37
verses.text: In tears they went forth with their children, for whom as being citizens they bewailed the exile, which, as they said, ought to be averted; no less did they grieve over the broken bonds of union, the severed ties of relationship.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:38
verses.text: And yet a fruitful year had smiled upon us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:39
verses.text: The city alone needed corn to be brought into it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:40
verses.text: It could have got help, if it had sought corn from the Italians whose children they were driving out.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:41
verses.text: Nothing is more shameful than to expel a man as a foreigner, and yet to claim his services as though he belonged  to us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:42
verses.text: How canst thou expel a man who lives on his own produce? How canst thou expel him who supplies thee with food? Thou retainest thy servant, and thrustest out thy kindred! Thou takest the corn, but showest no good feeling! Thou takest food by force, but dost not show gratitude!  50.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:43
verses.text: How wretched this is, how useless! For how can that be expedient which is not seemly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:44
verses.text: Of what great supplies from her corporations has Rome at times been deprived, yet she could not dismiss them and yet escape a famine, while waiting for a favourable breeze, and the provisions in the hoped-for ships.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:45
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:46
verses.text: How far more virtuous and expedient was that first-mentioned management! For what is so seemly or virtuous as when the needy are assisted by the gifts of the rich, when food is supplied to the hungry, when daily bread fails none? What so advantageous as when the cultivators are kept for the land, and the country people do not perish?  52.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:47
verses.text: What is virtuous, then, is also expedient, and what is expedient is virtuous.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 7:48
verses.text: On the other hand, what is not expedient is unseemly, and what is unseemly is also not expedient.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:2
verses.text: That those who put what is virtuous before what is useful are acceptable to God is shown by the example of Joshua, Caleb, and the other spies.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:4
verses.text: When could our fathers ever have thrown off their servitude, unless they had believed that it was not only shameful but even useless to serve the king of Egypt?  54.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:5
verses.text: Joshua, also, and Caleb, when sent to spy out the land, brought back the news that the land was indeed rich, but that it was inhabited by very fierce nations.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:6
verses.text: The people, terrified at the thought of war, refused to take possession of their land.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:7
verses.text: Joshua and Caleb, who had been sent as spies, tried to persuade them that the land was fruitful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:8
verses.text: They thought it unseemly to give way before the heathen; they chose rather to be stoned, which is what the people threatened, than to recede from their virtuous standpoint.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:9
verses.text: The others kept dissuading, the people exclaimed against it, saying they would have to fight against cruel and terrible nations; that they would fall in battle, and their wives and children would be left for a prey.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:11
verses.text: The anger of the Lord burst forth, so that He would kill all, but at the prayer of Moses He softened His judgment and put off His vengeance, knowing that He had already sufficiently punished those who were faithless, even if He spared them meanwhile and did not slay the unbelievers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:12
verses.text: However, He said they should not come to that land which they had refused, as a penalty for their unbelief; but their children and wives, who had not murmured, and who, owing to their sex and age, were guiltless, should receive the promised inheritance of that land.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:13
verses.text: So the bodies of those of twenty years old and upwards fell in the desert.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:14
verses.text: The punishment of the rest was put aside.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:15
verses.text: But they who had gone up with Joshua, and had thought fit to dissuade the people, died forthwith of a great plague.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:16
verses.text: Joshua and Caleb entered the land of promise together with those who were innocent by reason of age or sex.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:17
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:18
verses.text: The better part, therefore, preferred glory to safety; the worse part safety to virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 8:19
verses.text: But the divine judgment approved those who thought virtue was above what is useful, whilst it condemned those who preferred what seemed more in accordance with safety than with what is virtuous.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:2
verses.text: Cheating and dishonest ways of making money are utterly unfit for clerics whose duty is to serve all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:3
verses.text: They ought never to be involved in a money affair, unless it is one affecting a man's life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:4
verses.text: For them the example of David is given, that they should injure none, even when provoked; also the death of Naboth, to keep them from preferring life to virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:6
verses.text: Nothing is more odious than for a man to have no love for a virtuous life, but instead to be kept excited by an unworthy business in following out a low line of trade, or to be inflamed by an avaricious heart, and by day and by night to be eager to damage another's property, not to raise the soul to the splendour of a virtuous life, and not to regard the beauty of true praise.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:7
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:8
verses.text: Hence rise inheritances sought by cunning words and gained under pretence of being self-restrained and serious.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:9
verses.text: But this is absolutely abhorrent to the idea of a Christian man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:10
verses.text: For everything gained by craft and got together by cheating loses the merit of openness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:11
verses.text: Even amongst those  who have undertaken no duty in the ranks of the clergy it is considered unfitting to seek for the inheritance of another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:12
verses.text: Let those who are reaching the end of their life use their own judgment, so that they may freely make their wills as they think best, since they will not be able to amend them later.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:13
verses.text: For it is not honourable to divert the savings that belong to others or have been got together for them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:14
verses.text: It is further the duty of the priest or the cleric to be of use if possible to all and to be harmful to none.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:15
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:16
verses.text: If it is not possible to help one without injuring another, it is better to help neither than to press hard upon one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:17
verses.text: Therefore it is not a priest's duty to interfere in money affairs.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:18
verses.text: For here it must often happen that he who loses his case receives harm; and then he considers that he has been worsted through the action of the intervener.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:19
verses.text: It is a priest's duty to hurt no one, to be ready to help all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:20
verses.text: To be able to do this is in God's power alone.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:21
verses.text: In a case of life and death, without doubt it is a grave sin to injure him whom one ought to help when in danger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:22
verses.text: But it is foolish to gain others' hate in taking up money matters, though for the sake of a man's safety great trouble and toil may often be undertaken.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:23
verses.text: It is glorious in such a case to run risks.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:24
verses.text: Let, then, this be firmly held to in the priestly duties, namely, to injure none, not even when provoked and embittered by some injury.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:25
verses.text: Good was the man who said: "If I have rewarded evil to those who did me good".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:26
verses.text: For what glory is it if we do not injure him who has not injured us? But it is true virtue to forgive when injured.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:27
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:28
verses.text: What a virtuous action was that, when David wished rather to spare the king his enemy, though he could have injured him! How useful, too, it was, for it helped him when he succeeded to the throne.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:29
verses.text: For all learnt to observe faith to their king and not to seize the kingdom, but to fear and reverence him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:30
verses.text: Thus what is virtuous was preferred to what was useful, and then usefulness followed on what was virtuous.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:31
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:32
verses.text: But that he spared him was a small matter; he also grieved for him when slain in war, and mourned for him with tears, saying: "Ye mountains of Gilboa, let neither dew nor rain fall upon you; ye mountains of death, for there the shield of the mighty is cast away, the shield of Saul.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:33
verses.text: It is not anointed with oil, but with the blood of the wounded and the fat of the warriors.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:34
verses.text: The bow of Jonathan turned not back and the sword of Saul returned not empty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:35
verses.text: Saul and Jonathan were lovely and very dear, inseparable in life, and in death they were not divided.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:36
verses.text: They were swifter than eagles, they were stronger than lions.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:37
verses.text: Ye daughters of Israel, weep over Saul, who clothed you in scarlet with your ornaments, who put on gold upon your apparel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:38
verses.text: How are the mighty fallen in the midst of the battle! Jonathan was wounded even to death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:39
verses.text: I am distressed for thee, my brother Jonathan; very pleasant hast thou been unto me.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:40
verses.text: Thy love came to me like the love of women.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:41
verses.text: How have the mighty fallen and the longed-for weapons perished!  62.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:42
verses.text: What mother could weep thus for her only son as he wept here for his enemy? Who could follow his benefactor with such praise as that with which he followed the man who plotted against his life? How affectionately he grieved, with what deep feeling he bewailed him! The mountains dried up at the prophet's curse, and a divine power filled the judgment of him who spoke it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:43
verses.text: Therefore the elements themselves paid the penalty for witnessing the king's death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:44
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:45
verses.text: And what, in the case of holy Naboth, was the cause of his death, except his regard for a virtuous life? For when the king demanded the vineyard from him, promising to give him money, he refused the price for his father's heritage as unseemly, and preferred to shun such shame by dying.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:46
verses.text: "The Lord forbid it me, that I should give the inheritance of my fathers unto thee;" that is, that such reproach may not fall on me, that God may not allow such wickedness to be attained by force.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:47
verses.text: He is not speaking about the vines—nor has God care for vines or plots of ground—but he says it of his fathers' rights.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:48
verses.text: He could have received another or the king's vineyards and been his friend, wherein men think there is no small usefulness so far as this world is concerned.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:49
verses.text: But because it was base he thought it could not be useful, and so he preferred to endure danger with honour intact, rather than gain what was useful to his own disgrace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:50
verses.text: I am here again speaking of what is commonly understood as useful, not that in which there is the grace of virtuous life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:51
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:52
verses.text: The king could himself have taken it by force, but that he thought too shameless; then when Naboth was dead he grieved.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:53
verses.text: The Lord also declared that the woman's cruelty should be punished by a  fitting penalty, because she was unmindful of virtue and preferred a shameful gain.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:54
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:55
verses.text: Every kind of unfair action is shameful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:56
verses.text: Even in common things, false weights and unjust measures are accursed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:57
verses.text: And if fraud in the market or in business is punished, can it seem free from reproach if found in the midst of the performance of the duties of virtue? Solomon says: "A great and a little weight and divers measures are an abomination before the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 9:58
verses.text: Before that it also says: "A false balance is abomination to the Lord, but a just weight is acceptable to Him".

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:2
verses.text: We are warned not only in civil law, but also in the holy Scriptures, to avoid fraud in every agreement, as is clear from the example of Joshua and the Gibeonites.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:4
verses.text: In everything, therefore, good faith is seemly, justice is pleasing, due measure in equity is delightful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:5
verses.text: But what shall I say about contracts, and especially about the sale of land, or agreements, or covenants?
