Are there not rules just for the purpose of shutting out all false deceit, and to make him whose deceit is found out liable to double punishment? Everywhere, then, does regard for what is virtuous take the lead; it shuts out deceit, it expels fraud.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:6
verses.text: Wherefore the prophet David has rightly stated his judgment in general, saying: "He hath done no evil to his neighbour".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:7
verses.text: Fraud, then, ought to be wanting not only in contracts, in which the defects of those things which are for sale are ordered to be recorded (which contracts, unless the vendor has mentioned the defects, are rendered void by an action for fraud, although he has conveyed them fully to the purchaser), but it ought also to be absent in all else.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:8
verses.text: Candour must be shown, the truth must be made known.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:9
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:10
verses.text: The divine Scriptures have plainly stated (not indeed a legal rule of the lawyers but) the ancient judgment of the patriarchs on deceit, in that book of the Old Testament which is ascribed to Joshua the son of Nun.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:11
verses.text: When the report had gone forth among the various peoples that the sea was dried up at the crossing of the Hebrews; that water had flowed from the rock; that food was supplied daily from heaven in quantities large enough for so many thousands of the people; that the walls of Jericho had fallen at the sound of the holy trumpets, being overthrown by the noise of the shouts of the people; also, that the king of Ai was conquered and had been hung on a tree until the evening; then the Gibeonites, fearing his strong hand, came with guile, pretending that they were from a land very far away, and by travelling so long had rent their shoes and worn out their clothing, of which they showed proofs that it was growing old.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:12
verses.text: They said, too, that their reason for undergoing so much labour was their desire to obtain peace and to form friendship with the Hebrews, and began to ask Joshua to form an alliance with them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:13
verses.text: And he, being as yet ignorant of localities, and not knowing anything of the inhabitants, did not see through their deceit, nor did he enquire of God, but readily believed them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:14
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:15
verses.text: So sacred was one's plighted word held in those days that no one would believe that others could try to deceive.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:16
verses.text: Who could find fault with the saints in this, namely, that they should consider others to have the same feelings as themselves, and suppose no one would lie because truth was their own companion? They know not what deceit is, they gladly believe of others what they themselves are, whilst they cannot suspect others to be what they themselves are not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:17
verses.text: Hence Solomon says: "An innocent man believeth every word".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:18
verses.text: We must not blame his readiness to believe, but should rather praise his goodness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:19
verses.text: To know nothing of aught that may injure another, this is to be innocent.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:20
verses.text: And although he is cheated by another, still he thinks well of all, for he thinks there is good faith in all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:21
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:22
verses.text: Induced, therefore, by such considerations to believe them, he made an agreement, he gave them peace, and formed a union with them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:23
verses.text: But when he came to their country and the deceit was found out,—for though they lived quite close they pretended to be strangers,—the people of our fathers began to be angry at having been deceived.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:24
verses.text: Joshua, however, thought the peace they had made could not be broken (for it had been confirmed by an oath), for fear that, in punishing the treachery of others, he should be breaking his own pledge.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:25
verses.text: He made them pay the penalty, however, by forcing them to undertake the lowest kind of work.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 10:26
verses.text: The judgment was mild indeed, but it was a lasting one, for in their duties there abides the punishment of their ancient cunning,  handed down to this day in their hereditary service.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:2
verses.text: Having adduced examples of certain frauds found in a few passages of the rhetoricians, he shows that these and all others are more fully and plainly condemned in Scripture.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:4
verses.text: I shall say nothing of the snapping of fingers, or the naked dancing of the heir, at entering on an inheritance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:5
verses.text: These are well-known things.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:6
verses.text: Nor will I speak of the mass of fishes gathered up at a pretended fishing expedition to excite the buyer's desires.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:7
verses.text: For why did he show himself so eager for luxuries and delicacies as to allow a fraud of this character?  71.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:8
verses.text: What need is there for me to speak of that well-known story of the pleasant and quiet retreat at Syracuse and of the cunning of a Sicilian? For he having found a stranger, and knowing that he was anxious to buy an estate, asked him to his grounds for a meal.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:9
verses.text: He accepted, and on the following day he came.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:10
verses.text: There the sight of a great number of fishermen met his eyes, and a banquet laid out in the most splendid profusion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:11
verses.text: In the sight of the guests, fishers were placed in the garden-grounds, where no net had ever been laid before.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:12
verses.text: Each one in turn presented to the guests what he had taken, the fish were placed upon the table, and caught the glance of those who sat there.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:13
verses.text: The stranger wondered at the large quantity of fish and the number of boats there were.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:14
verses.text: The answer given was, that this was the great water supply, and that great numbers of fish came there because of the sweetness of the water.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:15
verses.text: To be brief, he drew on the stranger to be urgent in getting the grounds, he willingly allows himself to be induced to sell them, and seemingly with a heavy heart he receives the money.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:16
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:17
verses.text: On the next day the purchaser comes to the grounds with his friends, but finds no boat there.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:18
verses.text: On asking whether perhaps the fishermen were observing a festival on that day, he is told that, with the exception of yesterday, they were never wont to fish there; but what power had he to proceed against such a fraud, who had so shamefully grasped at such luxuries? For he who convicts another of a fault ought himself to be free from it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:19
verses.text: I will not therefore include such trifles as these under the power of ecclesiastical censure, for that altogether condemns every desire for dishonourable gain, and briefly, with few words, forbids every sharp and cunning action.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:20
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:21
verses.text: And what shall I say of him who claims to be the heir or legatee, on the proof of a will which, though falsified by others, yet was known to be so by him, and who tries to make a gain through another's crime, though even the laws of the state convict him who knowingly makes use of a false will, as guilty of a wrong action.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:22
verses.text: But the law of justice is plain, namely, that a good man ought not to go aside from the truth, nor to inflict an unjust loss on any one, nor to act at all deceitfully or to take part in any fraud.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:23
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:24
verses.text: What is clearer, however, on this point than the case of Ananias? He acted falsely as regards the price he got for his land, for he sold it and laid at the apostles' feet part of the price, pretending it was the whole amount.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:25
verses.text: For this he perished as guilty of fraud.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:26
verses.text: He might have offered nothing and have acted so without committing a fraud.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:27
verses.text: But as deceit entered into his action, he gained no favour for his liberality, but paid the penalty for his artifice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:28
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:29
verses.text: The Lord also in the Gospel rejected those coming to Him with guile, saying: "The foxes have holes," for He bids us live in simplicity and innocency of heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:30
verses.text: David also says: "Thou hast used deceit as a sharp razor," pointing out by this the treacherous man, just as an implement of this kind is used to help adorn a man, yet often wounds him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:31
verses.text: If any one makes a show of favour and yet plans deceit after the example of the traitor, so as to give up to death him whom he ought to guard, let him be looked on in the light of that instrument which is wont to wound owing to the vice of a drunken mind and a trembling hand.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 11:32
verses.text: Thus that man drunk with the wine of wickedness brought death on the high priest Ahimelech, through a terrible act of treachery, because he had received the prophet with hospitality when the king, roused by the stings of envy, was following him.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:2
verses.text: We may make no promise that is wrong, and if we have made an unjust oath, we may not keep it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:3
verses.text: It is shown that Herod sinned in this respect.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:4
verses.text: The vow taken by Jephtha is condemned, and so are all others which God does not desire to have paid to Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:5
verses.text: Lastly, the daughter of Jephtha is compared with the two Pythagoreans and is placed before them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:6
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:7
verses.text: A man's disposition ought to be undefiled and sound, so that he may utter words without dissimulation and possess his vessel in sanctification; that he may not delude his brother with false words nor promise aught dishonourable.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:8
verses.text: If he has made such a promise it is far better for him not to fulfil it, rather than to fulfil what is shameful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:9
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:10
verses.text: Often people bind themselves by a solemn oath, and, though they come to know that they ought not to have made the promise, fulfil it in consideration of their oath.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:11
verses.text: This is what Herod did, as we mentioned before.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:12
verses.text: For he made a shameful promise of reward to a dancer—and cruelly performed it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:13
verses.text: It was shameful, for a kingdom was promised for a dance; and it was cruel, for the death of a prophet is sacrificed for the sake of an oath.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:14
verses.text: How much better perjury would have been than the keeping of such an oath, if indeed that could be called perjury which a drunkard had sworn to in his wine-cups, or an effeminate profligate had promised whilst the dance was going on.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:15
verses.text: The prophet's head was brought in on a dish, and this was considered an act of good faith when it really was an act of madness!  78.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:16
verses.text: Never shall I be led to believe that the leader Jephtha made his vow otherwise than without thought, when he promised to offer to God whatever should meet him at the threshold of his house on his return.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:17
verses.text: For he repented of his vow, as afterwards his daughter came to meet him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:18
verses.text: He rent his clothes and said: "Alas, my daughter, thou hast entangled me, thou art become a source of trouble unto me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:19
verses.text: And though with pious fear and reverence he took upon himself the bitter fulfilment of his cruel task, yet he ordered and left to be observed an annual period of grief and mourning for future times.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:20
verses.text: It was a hard vow, but far more bitter was its fulfilment, whilst he who carried it out had the greatest cause to mourn.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:21
verses.text: Thus it became a rule and a law in Israel from year to year, as it says: "that the daughters of Israel went to lament the daughter of Jephtha the Gileadite four days in a year".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:22
verses.text: I cannot blame the man for holding it necessary to fulfil his vow, but yet it was a wretched necessity which could only be solved by the death of his child.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:23
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:24
verses.text: It is better to make no vow than to vow what God does not wish to be paid to Him to Whom the promise was made.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:25
verses.text: In the case of Isaac we have an example, for the Lord appointed a ram to be offered up instead of him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:26
verses.text: Therefore it is not always every promise that is to be fulfilled.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:27
verses.text: Nay, the Lord Himself often alters His determination, as the Scriptures point out.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:28
verses.text: For in the book called Numbers He had declared that He would punish the people with death and destroy them, but afterwards, when besought by Moses, He was reconciled again to them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:29
verses.text: And again, He said to Moses and Aaron: "Separate yourselves from among this congregation that I may consume them in a moment".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:30
verses.text: And when they separated from the assembly the earth suddenly clave asunder and opened her mouth and swallowed up Dathan and Abiram.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:31
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:32
verses.text: That example of Jephtha's daughter is far more glorious and ancient than that of the two Pythagoreans, which is accounted so notable among the philosophers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:33
verses.text: One of these, when condemned to death by the tyrant Dionysius, and when the day of his death was fixed, asked for leave to be granted him to go home, so as to provide for his family.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:34
verses.text: But for fear that he might break his faith and not return, he offered a surety for his own death, on condition that if he himself were absent on the appointed day, his surety would be ready to die in his stead.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:35
verses.text: The other did not refuse the conditions of suretyship which were proposed and awaited the day of death with a calm mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:36
verses.text: So the one did not withdraw himself and the other returned on the day appointed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:37
verses.text: This all seemed so wonderful that the tyrant sought their friendship whose destruction he had been anxious for.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:38
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:39
verses.text: What, then, in the case of esteemed and learned men is full of marvel, that in the case of a virgin is found to be far more splendid, far more glorious, as she says to her sorrowing father: "Do to me according to that which hath proceeded out of thy mouth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:40
verses.text: But she asked for a delay of two months in order that she might go about  with her companions upon the mountains to bewail fitly and dutifully her virginity now given up to death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:41
verses.text: The weeping of her companions did not move her, their grief prevailed not upon her, nor did their lamentations hold her back.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:42
verses.text: She allowed not the day to pass, nor did the hour escape her notice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 12:43
verses.text: She returned to her father as though returning according to her own desire, and of her own will urged him on when he was hesitating, and acted thus of her own free choice, so that what was at first an awful chance became a pious sacrifice.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:2
verses.text: Judith, after enduring many dangers for virtue's sake, gained very many and great benefits.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:4
verses.text: See! Judith presents herself to thee as worthy of admiration.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:5
verses.text: She approaches Holophernes, a man feared by the people, and surrounded by the victorious troops of the Assyrians.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:6
verses.text: At first she makes an impression on him by the grace of her form and the beauty of her countenance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:7
verses.text: Then she entraps him by the refinement of her speech.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:8
verses.text: Her first triumph was that she returned from the tent of the enemy with her purity unspotted.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:9
verses.text: Her second, that she gained a victory over a man, and put to flight the people by her counsel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:11
verses.text: The Persians were terrified at her daring.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:12
verses.text: And so what is admired in the case of those two Pythagoreans deserves also in her case our admiration, for she trembled not at the danger of death, nor even at the danger her modesty was in, which is a matter of greater concern to good women.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:13
verses.text: She feared not the blow of one scoundrel, nor even the weapons of a whole army.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:14
verses.text: She, a woman, stood between the lines of the combatants—right amidst victorious arms—heedless of death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:15
verses.text: As one looks at her overwhelming danger, one would say she went out to die; as one looks at her faith, one says she went but out to fight.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:16
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:17
verses.text: Judith then followed the call of virtue, and as she follows that, she wins great benefits.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:18
verses.text: It was virtuous to prevent the people of the Lord from giving themselves up to the heathen; to prevent them from betraying their native rites and mysteries, or from yielding up their consecrated virgins, their venerable widows, and modest matrons to barbarian impurity, or from ending the siege by a surrender.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:19
verses.text: It was virtuous for her to be willing to encounter danger on behalf of all, so as to deliver all from danger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:20
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 13:21
verses.text: How great must have been the power of her virtue, that she, a woman, should claim to give counsel on the chiefest matters and not leave it in the hands of the leaders of the people! How great, again, the power of her virtue to reckon for certain upon God to help her! How great her grace to find His help!.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:2
verses.text: How virtuous and useful was that which Elisha did.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:3
verses.text: This is compared with that oft-recounted act of the Greeks.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:4
verses.text: John gave up his life for virtue's sake, and Susanna for the same reason exposed herself to the danger of death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:5
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:6
verses.text: What did Elisha follow but virtue, when he brought the army of Syria who had come to take him as captive into Samaria, after having covered their eyes with blindness? Then he said: "O Lord, open their eyes that they may see".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:7
verses.text: And they saw.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:8
verses.text: But when the king of Israel wished to slay those that had entered and asked the prophet to give him leave to do so, he answered that they whose captivity was not brought about by strength of hand or weapons of war must not be slain, but that rather he should help them by supplying food.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:9
verses.text: Then they were refreshed with plenty of food.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:10
verses.text: And after that those Syrian robbers thought they must never again return to the land of Israel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:11
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:12
verses.text: How much nobler was this than that which the Greeks once did! For when two nations strove one with the other to gain glory and supreme power, and one of them had the opportunity to burn the ships of the other secretly, they thought it a shameful thing to do so, and preferred to gain a less advantage honourably than a greater one in shameful wise.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:13
verses.text: They, indeed, could not act thus without disgrace to themselves, and entrap by this plot those who had banded together for the sake of ending the Persian war.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:14
verses.text: Though they could deny it in word, yet they could never but blush at the thought of it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:15
verses.text: Elisha, however, wished to save, not destroy, those who were deceived indeed, though not by some foul act, and had been struck blind by the power of the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:16
verses.text: For it was seemly to spare an enemy, and to grant his life to an adversary when indeed he could have taken it, had he not spared it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:17
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:18
verses.text: It is plain, then, that whatever is  seemly is always useful.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:19
verses.text: For holy Judith by seemly disregard for her own safety put an end to the dangers of the siege, and by her own virtue won what was useful to all in common.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:20
verses.text: And Elisha gained more renown by pardoning than he would have done by slaying, and preserved those enemies whom he had taken for greater usefulness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:21
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:22
verses.text: And what else did John have in mind but what is virtuous, so that he could not endure a wicked union even in the king's case, saying: "It is not lawful for thee to have her to wife".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:23
verses.text: He could have been silent, had he not thought it unseemly for himself not to speak the truth for fear of death, or to make the prophetic office yield to the king, or to indulge in flattery.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:24
verses.text: He knew well that he would die as he was against the king, but he preferred virtue to safety.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:25
verses.text: Yet what is more expedient than the suffering which brought glory to the saint.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:26
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:27
verses.text: Holy Susanna, too, when threatened with the fear of false witness, seeing herself hard pressed on one side by danger, on the other by disgrace, preferred to avoid disgrace by a virtuous death rather than to endure and live a shameful life in the desire to save herself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:28
verses.text: So while she fixed her mind on virtue, she also preserved her life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:29
verses.text: But if she had preferred what seemed to her to be useful to preserve life, she would never have gained such great renown, nay, perhaps—and that would have been not only useless but even dangerous—she might even not have escaped the penalty for her crime.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:30
verses.text: We note, therefore, that whatsoever is shameful cannot be useful, nor, again, can that which is virtuous be useless.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 14:31
verses.text: For usefulness is ever the double of virtue, and virtue of usefulness.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:2
verses.text: After mentioning a noble action of the Romans, the writer shows from the deeds of Moses that he had the greatest regard for what is virtuous.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:4
verses.text: It is related as a memorable deed of a Roman general, that when the physician of a hostile king came to him and promised to give him poison, he sent him back bound to the enemy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:5
verses.text: In truth, it is a noble thing for a man to refuse to gain the victory by foul acts, after he has entered on the struggle for power.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:6
verses.text: He did not consider virtue to lie in victory, but declared that to be a shameful victory unless it was gained with honour.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:7
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:8
verses.text: Let us return to our hero Moses, and to loftier deeds, to show they were both superior as well as earlier.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:9
verses.text: The king of Egypt would not let the people of our fathers go.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:10
verses.text: Then Moses bade the priest Aaron to stretch his rod over all the waters of Egypt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:11
verses.text: Aaron stretched it out, and the water of the river was turned into blood.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:12
verses.text: None could drink the water, and all the Egyptians were perishing with thirst; but there was pure water flowing in abundance for the fathers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:13
verses.text: They sprinkled ashes toward heaven, and sores and burning boils came upon man and beast.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:14
verses.text: They brought down hail mingled with flaming fire, and all things were destroyed upon the land.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:15
verses.text: Moses prayed, and all things were restored to their former beauty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:16
verses.text: The hail ceased, the sores were healed, the rivers gave their wonted draught.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:17
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:18
verses.text: Then, again, the land was covered with thick darkness for the space of three days, because Moses had raised his hand and spread out the darkness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:19
verses.text: All the first-born of Egypt died, whilst all the offspring of the Hebrews was left unharmed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:20
verses.text: Moses was asked to put an end to these horrors, and he prayed and obtained his request.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:21
verses.text: In the one case it was a fact worthy of praise that he checked himself from joining in deceit; in the other it was noteworthy how, by his innate goodness, he turned aside from the foe those divinely ordered punishments.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:22
verses.text: He was indeed, as it is written, gentle and meek.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:23
verses.text: He knew that the king would not keep true to his promises, yet he thought it right and good to pray when asked to do so, to bless when wronged, to forgive when besought.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:24
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:25
verses.text: He cast down his rod and it became a serpent which devoured the serpents of Egypt; this signifying that the Word should become Flesh to destroy the poison of the dread serpent by the forgiveness and pardon of sins.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:26
verses.text: For the rod stands for the Word that is true—royal—filled with power—and glorious in ruling.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:27
verses.text: The rod became a serpent; so He Who was the Son of God begotten of the Father became the Son of man born of a woman, and lifted, like the serpent, on the cross, poured His healing medicine on the wounds of man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:28
verses.text: Wherefore the Lord Himself says: "As  Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, so must the Son of Man be lifted up".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:29
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:30
verses.text: Again, another sign which Moses gave points to our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:31
verses.text: He put his hand into his bosom, and drew it out again, and his hand was become as snow.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:32
verses.text: A second time he put it in and drew it out, and it was again like the appearance of human flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:33
verses.text: This signified first the original glory of the Godhead of the Lord Jesus, and then the assumption of our flesh, in which truth all nations and peoples must believe.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:34
verses.text: So he put in his hand, for Christ is the right hand of God; and whosoever does not believe in His Godhead and Incarnation is punished as a sinner; like that king who, whilst not believing open and plain signs, yet afterwards, when punished, prayed that he might find mercy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 15:35
verses.text: How great, then, Moses' regard for virtue must have been is shown by these proofs, and especially by the fact that he offered himself on behalf of the people, praying that God would either forgive the people or blot him out of the book of the living.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 16

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 16:2
verses.text: After saying a few words about Tobit he demonstrates that Raguel surpassed the philosophers in virtue.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 16:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 16:4
verses.text: Tobit also clearly portrayed in his life true virtue, when he left the feast and buried the dead, and invited the needy to the meals at his own poor table.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 16:5
verses.text: And Raguel is a still brighter example.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 16:6
verses.text: For he, in his regard for virtue, when asked to give his daughter in marriage, was not silent regarding his daughter's faults, for fear of seeming to get the better of the suitor by silence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 16:7
verses.text: So when Tobit the son of Tobias asked that his daughter might be given him, he answered that, according to the law, she ought to be given him as near of kin, but that he had already given her to six men, and all of them were dead.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 16:8
verses.text: This just man, then, feared more for others than for himself, and wished rather that his daughter should remain unmarried than that others should run risks in consequence of their union with her.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 16:9
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 16:10
verses.text: How simply he settled all the questions of the philosophers! They talk about the defects of a house, whether they ought to be concealed or made known by the vendor.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 16:11
verses.text: Raguel was quite certain that his daughter's faults ought not to be kept secret.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 16:12
verses.text: And, indeed, he had not been eager to give her up—he was asked for her.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 16:13
verses.text: We can have no doubt how much more nobly he acted than those philosophers, when we consider how much more important a daughter's future is than some mere money affair.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:2
verses.text: With what virtuous feelings the fathers of old hid the sacred fires when on the point of going into captivity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:4
verses.text: Let us consider, again, that deed done at the time of the captivity, which has attained the highest degree of virtue and glory.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:5
verses.text: Virtue is checked by no adversities, for it rises up among them, and prevails here rather than in prosperity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:6
verses.text: 'Mid chains or arms, 'mid flames or slavery (which is harder for freemen to bear than any punishment), 'midst the pains of the dying, the destruction of their country, the fears of the living, or the blood of the slain,—amidst all this our forefathers failed not in their care and thought for what is virtuous.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:7
verses.text: Amidst the ashes and dust of their fallen country it glowed and shone forth brightly in pious efforts.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:8
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:9
verses.text: For when our fathers were carried away into Persia, certain priests, who then were in the service of Almighty God, secretly buried in the valley the fire taken from the altar of the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:10
verses.text: There was there an open pit, with no water in it, and not accessible for the wants of the people, in a spot unknown and free from intruders.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:11
verses.text: There they sealed the hidden fire with the sacred mark and in secret.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:12
verses.text: They were not anxious to bury gold or to hide up silver to preserve it for their children, but in their own great peril, thinking of all that was virtuous, they thought the sacred fire ought to be preserved so that impure men might not defile it, nor the blood of the slain extinguish it, nor the heaps of miserable ruins cover it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:13
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:14
verses.text: So they went to Persia, free only in their religion; for that alone could not be torn from them by their captivity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:15
verses.text: After a length of time, indeed, according to God's good pleasure, He put it into the Persian king's heart to order the temple in Judea to be restored, and the regular customs to be again rebuilt at Jerusalem.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:16
verses.text: To carry out this work of his the Persian king appointed  the priest Nehemiah.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:17
verses.text: He took with him the grandchildren of those priests who on leaving their native soil had hidden the sacred fire to save it from perishing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:18
verses.text: But on arriving, as we are told in the history of the fathers, they found not fire but water.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:19
verses.text: And when fire was wanting to burn upon the altars, the priest Nehemiah bade them draw the water, to bring it to him, and to sprinkle it upon the wood.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:20
verses.text: Then, O wondrous sight! though the sky had been overcast with clouds, suddenly the sun shone forth, a great fire flamed forth, so that all, wonder-stricken at such a clear sign of the favour of the Lord, were filled with joy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:21
verses.text: Nehemiah prayed; the priests sang a hymn of praise to God, when the sacrifice was completed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:22
verses.text: Nehemiah again bade the remainder of the water to be poured upon the larger stones.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:23
verses.text: And when this was done a flame burst forth whilst the light shining from off the altar shone more brightly yet.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:24
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:25
verses.text: When this sign became known, the king of Persia ordered a temple to be built on that spot where the fire had been hidden and the water afterwards found, to which many gifts were made.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:26
verses.text: They who were with holy Nehemiah called it Naphthar,—which means cleansing—by many it is called Nephi.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:27
verses.text: It is to be found also in the history of the prophet Jeremiah, that he bade those who should come after him to take of the fire.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:28
verses.text: That is the fire which fell on Moses' sacrifice and consumed it, as it is written: "There came a fire out from the Lord and consumed upon the altar all the whole burnt-offering".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:29
verses.text: The sacrifice must be hallowed with this fire only.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:30
verses.text: Therefore, also, fire went out from the Lord upon the sons of Aaron who wished to offer strange fire, and consumed them, so that their dead bodies were cast forth without the camp.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:31
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:32
verses.text: Jeremiah coming to a spot found there a house like a cave, and brought into it the tabernacle, the ark, and the altar of incense, and closed up the entrance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:33
verses.text: And when those who had come with him examined it rather closely to mark the spot, they could not discover nor find it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:34
verses.text: When Jeremiah understood what they wanted he said: "The spot will remain unknown until God shall gather His people together and be gracious to them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 17:35
verses.text: Then God shall reveal these things and the majesty of the Lord shall appear".

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:2
verses.text: In the narration of that event already mentioned, and especially of the sacrifice offered by Nehemiah, is typified the Holy Spirit and Christian baptism.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:3
verses.text: The sacrifice of Moses and Elijah and the history of Noah are also referred to the same.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:5
verses.text: We form the congregation of the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:6
verses.text: We recognize the propitiation of our Lord God, which our Propitiator wrought in His passion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:7
verses.text: I think, too, we cannot leave out of sight that fire when we read that the Lord Jesus baptizes with the Holy Spirit and with fire, as John said in his Gospel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:8
verses.text: Rightly was the sacrifice consumed, for it was for sin.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:9
verses.text: But that fire was a type of the Holy Spirit Who was to come down after the Lord's ascension, and forgive the sins of all, and Who like fire inflames the mind and faithful heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:10
verses.text: Wherefore Jeremiah, after receiving the Spirit, says: "It became in my heart as a burning fire flaming in my bones, and I am vile and cannot bear it".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:11
verses.text: In the Acts of the Apostles, also, when the Holy Spirit descended upon the apostles and those others who were waiting for the Promise of the Father, we read that tongues as of fire were distributed among them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:12
verses.text: The soul of each one was so uplifted by His influence that they were supposed to be full of new wine, who instead had received the gift of a diversity of tongues.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:13
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:14
verses.text: What else can this mean—namely, that fire became water and water called forth fire—but that spiritual grace burns out our sins through fire, and through water cleanses them? For sin is washed away and it is burnt away.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:15
verses.text: Wherefore the Apostle says: "The fire shall try every man's work of what sort it is".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:16
verses.text: And further on: "If any man's work shall be burned, he shall suffer loss: but he himself shall be saved; yet so as by fire".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:17
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:18
verses.text: This, then, we have stated, so as to prove that sins are burnt out by means of fire.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:19
verses.text: We know now that this is in truth the sacred fire which then, as a type of the future remission of sins, came down upon the sacrifice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:20
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:21
verses.text: This fire is hidden in the time of captivity, during which sin reigns, but in the time of liberty it is brought forth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:22
verses.text: And though it is changed into the appearance of water, yet it preserves its nature as fire so as to consume the sacrifice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:23
verses.text: Do not wonder when thou readest that God the Father  said: "I am a consuming fire".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:24
verses.text: And again: "They have forsaken Me, the fountain of living water".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:25
verses.text: The Lord Jesus, too, like a fire inflamed the hearts of those who heard Him, and like a fount of waters cooled them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:26
verses.text: For He Himself said in His Gospel that He came to send fire on the earth and to supply a draught of living waters to those who thirst.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:27
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:28
verses.text: In the time of Elijah, also, fire came down when he challenged the prophets of the heathen to light up the altar without fire.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:29
verses.text: When they could not do so, he poured water thrice over his victim, so that the water ran round about the altar; then he cried out and the fire fell from the Lord from heaven and consumed the burnt-offering.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:30
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:31
verses.text: Thou art that victim.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:32
verses.text: Contemplate in silence each single point.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:33
verses.text: The breath of the Holy Spirit descends on thee, He seems to burn thee when He consumes thy sins.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:34
verses.text: The sacrifice which was consumed in the time of Moses was a sacrifice for sin, wherefore Moses said, as is written in the book of the Maccabees: "Because the sacrifice for sin was not to be eaten, it was consumed".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:35
verses.text: Does it not seem to be consumed for thee when in the sacrament of baptism the whole outer man perishes? "Our old man is crucified," the Apostle exclaims.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:36
verses.text: Herein, as the example of the fathers teaches us, the Egyptian is swallowed up—the Hebrew arises renewed by the Holy Spirit, as he also crossed the Red Sea dryshod—where our fathers were baptized in the cloud and in the sea.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:37
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:38
verses.text: In the flood, too, in Noah's time all flesh died, though just Noah was preserved together with his family.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:39
verses.text: Is not a man consumed when all that is mortal is cut off from life? The outer man is destroyed, but the inner is renewed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:40
verses.text: Not in baptism alone but also in repentance does this destruction of the flesh tend to the growth of the spirit, as we are taught on the Apostle's authority, when holy Paul says: "I have judged as though I were present him that hath so done this deed, to deliver him unto Satan for the destruction of the flesh, that the spirit may be saved in the day of our Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:41
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 18:42
verses.text: We seem to have made a somewhat lengthy digression for the sake of regarding this wonderful mystery, in desiring to unfold more fully this sacrament which has been revealed to us, and which, indeed, is as full of virtue as it is full of religious awe.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:2
verses.text: The crime committed by the inhabitants of Gibeah against the wife of a certain Levite is related, and from the vengeance taken it is inferred how the idea of virtue must have filled the heart of those people of old.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:4
verses.text: What regard for virtue our forefathers had to avenge by a war the wrongs of one woman which had been brought on her by her violation at the hands of profligate men! Nay, when the people were conquered, they vowed that they would not give their daughters in marriage to the tribe of Benjamin! That tribe had remained without hope of posterity, had they not received leave of necessity to use deceit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:5
verses.text: And this permission does not seem to fail in giving fitting punishment for violation, since they were only allowed to enter on a union by a rape, and not through the sacrament of marriage.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:6
verses.text: And indeed it was right that they who had broken another's intercourse should themselves lose their marriage rites.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:7
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:8
verses.text: How full of pitiful traits is this story! A man, it says, a Levite, had taken to himself a wife, who I suppose was called a concubine from the word "concubitus".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:9
verses.text: She some time afterwards, as is wont to happen, offended at certain things, betook herself to her father, and was with him four months.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:10
verses.text: Then her husband arose and went to the house of his father-in-law, to reconcile himself with his wife, to win her back and take her home again.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:11
verses.text: The woman ran to meet him and brought her husband into her father's house.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:12
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:13
verses.text: The maiden's father rejoiced and went to meet him, and the man stayed with him three days, and they ate and rested.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:14
verses.text: On the next day the Levite arose at daybreak, but was detained by his father-in-law, that he might not so quickly lose the pleasure of his company.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:15
verses.text: Again on the next and the third day the maiden's father did not suffer his son-in-law to start, until their joy and mutual regard was complete.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:16
verses.text: But on the seventh day, when it was already drawing to a close, after a pleasant meal, having urged the approach of the coming night, so as to make him think he ought to sleep amongst friends rather than strangers, he  was unable to keep him, and so let him go together with his daughter.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:17
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:18
verses.text: When some little progress was made, though night was threatening to come on, and they were close by the town of the Jebusites, on the slave's request that his lord should turn aside there, he refused, because it was not a city of the children of Israel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:19
verses.text: He meant to get as far as Gibeah, which was inhabited by the people of the tribe of Benjamin.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:20
verses.text: But when they arrived there was no one to receive them with hospitality, except a stranger of advanced age—When he had looked upon them he asked the Levite: Whither goest thou and whence dost thou come? On his answering that he was travelling and was making for Mount Ephraim and that there was no one to take him in, the old man offered him hospitality and prepared a meal.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:21
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:22
verses.text: And when they were satisfied and the tables were removed, vile men rushed up and surrounded the house.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:23
verses.text: Then the old man offered these wicked men his daughter, a virgin, and the concubine with whom she shared her bed, only that violence might not be inflicted on his guest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:24
verses.text: But when reason did no good and violence prevailed, the Levite parted from his wife, and they knew her and abused her all that night.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:25
verses.text: Overcome by this cruelty or by grief at her wrong, she fell at the door of their host where her husband had entered, and gave up the ghost, with the last effort of her life guarding the feelings of a good wife so as to preserve for her husband at least her mortal remains.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:26
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:27
verses.text: When this became known (to be brief) almost all the people of Israel broke out into war.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:28
verses.text: The war remained doubtful with an uncertain issue, but in the third engagement the people of Benjamin were delivered to the people of Israel, and being condemned by the divine judgment paid the penalty for their profligacy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:29
verses.text: The sentence, further, was that none of the people of the fathers should give his daughter in marriage to them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:30
verses.text: This was confirmed by a solemn oath.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:31
verses.text: But relenting at having laid so hard a sentence on their brethren, they moderated their severity so as to give them in marriage those maidens that had lost their parents, whose fathers had been slain for their sins, or to give them the means of finding a wife by a raid.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:32
verses.text: Because of the villainy of so foul a deed, they who have violated another's marriage rights were shown to be unworthy to ask for marriage.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:33
verses.text: But for fear that one tribe might perish from the people, they connived at the deceit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:34
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:35
verses.text: What great regard our forefathers had for virtue is shown by the fact that forty thousand men drew the sword against their brethren of the tribe of Benjamin in their desire to avenge the wrong done to modesty, for they would not endure the violation of chastity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:36
verses.text: And so in that war on both sides there fell sixty-five thousand warriors, whilst their cities were burnt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:37
verses.text: And when at first the people of Israel were defeated, yet unmoved by fear at the reverses of the war, they disregarded the sorrow the avenging of chastity cost them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 19:38
verses.text: They rushed into the battle ready to wash out with their own blood the stains of the crime that had been committed.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:2
verses.text: After the terrible siege of Samaria was ended in accordance with Elisha's prophecy, he relates what regard the four lepers showed for what was virtuous.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:3
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:4
verses.text: Why need we wonder that the people of the Lord had regard for what was seemly and virtuous when even the lepers—as we read in the books of the Kings—showed concern for what is virtuous?  118.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:5
verses.text: There was a great famine in Samaria, for the army of the Syrians was besieging it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:6
verses.text: The king in his anxiety was making the round of the guards on the walls when a woman addressed him, saying: This woman persuaded me to give up my son—and I gave him up, and we boiled him and did eat him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:7
verses.text: And she promised that she would afterwards bring her son and that we should eat his flesh together, but now she hath hidden her son and will not bring him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:8
verses.text: The king was troubled because these women seemed to have fed not merely on human bodies, but on the bodies of their own children; and being moved by an example of such awful misery, threatened the prophet Elisha with death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:9
verses.text: For he believed it was in his power to break up the siege and to avert the famine; or else he was angry because the prophet had not allowed the king to smite the Syrians whom he had struck with blindness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:10
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:11
verses.text: Elisha sat with the elders at Bethel, and before the king's messenger came to him he said to the elders: "See ye how the son of that murderess hath sent to take away mine head?" Then the messenger  entered and brought the king's command threatening instant danger to his life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:12
verses.text: Him the prophet answered: "To-morrow about this time shall a measure of fine flour be sold for a shekel, and two measures of barley for a shekel in the gate of Samaria".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:13
verses.text: Then when the messenger sent by the king would not believe it, saying: "If the Lord would rain abundance of corn from heaven, not even so would that come about," Elisha said to him: "Because thou hast not believed, thou shalt see it with thine eyes, but shall not eat of it".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:14
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:15
verses.text: And suddenly in the camp of Syria was there heard, as it were, a sound of chariots and a loud noise of horses and the noise of a great host, and the tumult of some vast battle.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:16
verses.text: And the Syrians thought that the king of Israel had called to his help in the battle the king of Egypt and the king of the Amorites, and they fled at dawn leaving their tents, for they feared that they might be crushed by the sudden arrival of fresh foes, and would not be able to withstand the united forces of the kings.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:17
verses.text: This was unknown in Samaria, for they dared not go out of the town, being overcome with fear and also being weak through hunger.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:18
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:19
verses.text: But there were four lepers at the gate of the city to whom life was a misery, and to die would be gain.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:20
verses.text: And they said one to another: "Behold we sit here and die.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:21
verses.text: If we enter into the city, we shall die with hunger; if we remain here, there are no means of living at hand for us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:22
verses.text: Let us go to the Syrian camp, either they will quickly kill us or grant us the means of safety".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:23
verses.text: So they went and entered into the camp, and behold, all was forsaken by the enemy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:24
verses.text: Entering the tents, first of all on finding food they satisfied their hunger, then they laid hold of as much gold and silver as they could.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:25
verses.text: But whilst they were intent on the booty alone, they arranged to announce to the king that the Syrians had fled, for they thought this more virtuous than to withhold the information and keep for themselves the plunder gained by deceit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:26
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:27
verses.text: At this information the people went forth and plundered the Syrian camp.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:28
verses.text: The supplies of the enemy produced an abundance, and brought about cheapness of corn according to the prophet's word: "A measure of fine flour for a shekel, and two measures of barley for a shekel".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 20:29
verses.text: In this rejoicing of the people, that officer on whose hand the king leaned died, being crushed and trodden under foot by the people as the crowds kept hurrying to go out or returned with great rejoicing.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 21

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 21:2
verses.text: Esther in danger of her life followed the grace of virtue; nay, even a heathen king did so, when death was threatened to a man most friendly to him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 21:3
verses.text: For friendship must ever be combined with virtue, as the examples of Jonathan and Ahimelech show.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 21:4
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 21:5
verses.text: Why did Queen Esther expose herself to death and not fear the wrath of a fierce king? Was it not to save her people from death, an act both seemly and virtuous? The king of Persia himself also, though fierce and proud, yet thought it seemly to show honour to the man who had given information about a plot which had been laid against himself, to save a free people from slavery, to snatch them from death, and not to spare him who had pressed on such unseemly plans.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 21:6
verses.text: So finally he handed over to the gallows the man that stood second to himself, and whom he counted chief among all his friends, because he considered that he had dishonoured him by his false counsels.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 21:7
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 21:8
verses.text: For that commendable friendship which maintains virtue is to be preferred most certainly to wealth, or honours, or power.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 21:9
verses.text: It is not wont to be preferred to virtue indeed, but to follow after it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 21:10
verses.text: So it was with Jonathan, who for his affection's sake avoided not his father's displeasure nor the danger to his own safety.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 21:11
verses.text: So, too, it was with Ahimelech, who, to preserve the duties of hospitality, thought he must endure death rather than betray his friend when fleeing.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:2
verses.text: Virtue must never be given up for the sake of a friend.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:3
verses.text: If, however, one has to bear witness against a friend, it must be done with caution.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:4
verses.text: Between friends what candour is needed in opening the heart, what magnanimity in suffering, what freedom in finding fault! Friendship is the guardian of virtues, which are not to be found but in men of like character.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:5
verses.text: It must be mild in rebuking and averse to seeking its own advantage; whence it happens that true friends are scarce among the rich.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:6
verses.text: What is the dignity of friendship? The treachery of a friend, as it is worse, so it is also more hateful than another's, as is recognized from the example of Judas and of Job's friends.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:7
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:8
verses.text: Nothing, then, must be set before  virtue; and that it may never be set aside by the desire for friendship, Scripture also gives us a warning on the subject of friendship.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:9
verses.text: There are, indeed various questions raised among philosophers; for instance whether a man ought for the sake of a friend to plot against his country or not, so as to serve his friend? Whether it is right to break one's faith, and so aid and maintain a friend's advantage?  126.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:10
verses.text: And Scripture also says: "A maul, and a sword, and a sharp arrow, so is a man that beareth false witness against his friend".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:11
verses.text: But note what it adds.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:12
verses.text: It blames not witness given against a friend, but false witness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:13
verses.text: For what if the cause of God or of one's country compels one to give witness? Ought friendship to take a higher place than our religion, or our love for our fellow-citizens? In these matters, however, true witness is required so that a friend may not be assailed by the treachery of a friend, by whose good faith he ought to be acquitted.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:14
verses.text: A man, then, ought never to please a friend who desires evil, or to plot against one who is innocent.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:15
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:16
verses.text: Certainly, if it is necessary to give witness, then, when one knows of any fault in a friend, one ought to rebuke him secretly—if he does not listen, one must do it openly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:17
verses.text: For rebukes are good, and often better than a silent friendship.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:18
verses.text: Even if a friend thinks himself hurt, still rebuke him; and if the bitterness of the correction wounds his mind, still rebuke him and fear not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:19
verses.text: "The wounds of a friend are better than the kisses of flatterers".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:20
verses.text: Rebuke, then, thy erring friend; forsake not an innocent one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:21
verses.text: For friendship ought to be steadfast and to rest firm in true affection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:22
verses.text: We ought not to change our friends in childish fashion at some idle fancy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:23
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:24
verses.text: Open thy breast to a friend that he may be faithful to thee, and that thou mayest receive from him the delight of thy life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:25
verses.text: "For a faithful friend is the medicine of life and the grace of immortality".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:26
verses.text: Give way to a friend as to an equal, and be not ashamed to be beforehand with thy friend in doing kindly duties.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:27
verses.text: For friendship knows nothing of pride.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:28
verses.text: So the wise man says: "Do not blush to greet a friend".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:29
verses.text: Do not desert a friend in time of need, nor forsake him nor fail him, for friendship is the support of life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:30
verses.text: Let us then bear our burdens as the Apostle has taught: for he spoke to those whom the charity of the same one body had embraced together.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:31
verses.text: If friends in prosperity help friends, why do they not also in times of adversity offer their support? Let us aid by giving counsel, let us offer our best endeavours, let us sympathize with them with all our heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:32
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:33
verses.text: If necessary, let us endure for a friend even hardship.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:34
verses.text: Often enmity has to be borne for the sake of a friend's innocence; oftentimes revilings, if one defends and answers for a friend who is found fault with and accused.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:35
verses.text: Do not be afraid of such displeasure, for the voice of the just says: "Though evil come upon me, I will endure it for a friend's sake".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:36
verses.text: In adversity, too, a friend is proved, for in prosperity all seem to be friends.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:37
verses.text: But as in adversity patience and endurance are needed, so in prosperity strong influence is wanted to check and confute the arrogance of a friend who becomes overbearing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:38
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:39
verses.text: How nobly Job when he was in adversity said: "Pity me, my friends, pity me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:40
verses.text: That is not a cry as it were of misery, but rather one of blame.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:41
verses.text: For when he was unjustly reproached by his friends, he answered: "Pity me, my friends," that is, ye ought to show pity, but instead ye assail and overwhelm a man with whose sufferings ye ought to show sympathy for friendship's sake.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:42
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:43
verses.text: Preserve, then, my sons, that friendship ye have begun with your brethren, for nothing in the world is more beautiful than that.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:44
verses.text: It is indeed a comfort in this life to have one to whom thou canst open thy heart, with whom thou canst share confidences, and to whom thou canst entrust the secrets of thy heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:45
verses.text: It is a comfort to have a trusty man by thy side, who will rejoice with thee in prosperity, sympathize in troubles, encourage in persecution.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:46
verses.text: What good friends those Hebrew children were whom the flames of the fiery furnace did not separate from their love of each other! Of them we have already spoken.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:47
verses.text: Holy David says well: "Saul and Jonathan were lovely and pleasant, inseparable in their life, in death they were not divided".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:48
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:49
verses.text: This is the fruit of friendship; and so faith may not be put aside for the sake of friendship.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:50
verses.text: He cannot be a friend to a man who has been unfaithful to God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:51
verses.text: Friendship is the guardian of pity and the teacher of equality, so as to make the superior equal to the inferior, and the inferior  to the superior.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:52
verses.text: For there can be no friendship between diverse characters, and so the good-will of either ought to be mutually suited to the other.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:53
verses.text: Let not authority be wanting to the inferior if the matter demands it, nor humility to the superior.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:54
verses.text: Let him listen to the other as though he were of like position—an equal, and let the other warn and reprove like a friend, not from a desire to show off, but with a deep feeling of love.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:55
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:56
verses.text: Let not thy warning be harsh, nor thy rebuke bitter, for as friendship ought to avoid flattery, so, too, ought it to be free from arrogance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:57
