verses.text: For what is a friend but a partner in love, to whom thou unitest and attachest thy soul, and with whom thou blendest so as to desire from being two to become one; to whom thou entrustest thyself as to a second self, from whom thou fearest nothing, and from whom thou demandest nothing dishonourable for the sake of thine own advantage.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:58
verses.text: Friendship is not meant as a source of revenue, but is full of seemliness, full of grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:59
verses.text: Friendship is a virtue, not a way of making money.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:60
verses.text: It is produced, not by money, but by esteem; not by the offer of rewards, but by a mutual rivalry in doing kindnesses.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:61
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:62
verses.text: Lastly, the friendships of the poor are generally better than those of the rich, and often the rich are without friends, whilst the poor have many.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:63
verses.text: For true friendship cannot exist where there is lying flattery.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:64
verses.text: Many try fawningly to please the rich, but no one cares to make pretence to a poor man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:65
verses.text: Whatsoever is stated to a poor man is true, his friendship is free from envy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:66
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:67
verses.text: What is more precious than friendship which is shared alike by angels and by men? Wherefore the Lord Jesus says: "Make to yourselves friends of the mammon of unrighteousness, that they may receive you into eternal habitations".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:68
verses.text: God Himself makes us friends instead of servants, as He Himself says: "Ye are My friends if ye do whatsoever I command you".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:69
verses.text: He gave us a pattern of friendship to follow.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:70
verses.text: We are to fulfil the wish of a friend, to unfold to him our secrets which we hold in our own hearts, and are not to disregard his confidences.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:71
verses.text: Let us show him our heart and he will open his to us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:72
verses.text: Therefore He says: "I have called you friends, for I have made known unto you all things whatsoever I have heard of My Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:73
verses.text: A friend, then, if he is a true one, hides nothing; he pours forth his soul as the Lord Jesus poured forth the mysteries of His Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:74
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:75
verses.text: So he who does the will of God is His friend and is honoured with this name.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:76
verses.text: He who is of one mind with Him, he too is His friend.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:77
verses.text: For there is unity of mind in friends, and no one is more hateful than the man that injures friendship.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:78
verses.text: Hence in the traitor the Lord found this the worst point on which to condemn his treachery, namely, that he gave no sign of gratitude and had mingled the poison of malice at the table of friendship.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:79
verses.text: So He says: "It was thou, a man of like mind, My guide and Mine acquaintance, who ever didst take pleasant meals with Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:80
verses.text: That is: it could not be endured, for thou didst fall upon Him Who granted grace to thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:81
verses.text: "For if My enemy had reproached Me I could have borne it, and I would have hid Myself from him who hated Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:82
verses.text: An enemy can be avoided; a friend cannot, if he desires to lay a plot.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:83
verses.text: Let us guard against him to whom we do not entrust our plans; we cannot guard against him to whom we have already entrusted them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:84
verses.text: And so to show up all the hatefulness of the sin He did not say: Thou, My servant, My apostle; but thou, a man of like mind with Me; that is: thou art not My but thy own betrayer, for thou didst betray a man of like mind with thyself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:85
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:86
verses.text: The Lord Himself, when He was displeased with the three princes who had not deferred to holy Job, wished to pardon them through their friend, so that the prayer of friendship might win remission of sins.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:87
verses.text: Therefore Job asked and God pardoned.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:88
verses.text: Friendship helped them whom arrogance had harmed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:89
Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:90
verses.text: These things I have left with you, my children, that you may guard them in your minds—you yourselves will prove whether they will be of any advantage.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Duties of the Clergy Book III 22:91
verses.text: Meanwhile they offer you a large number of examples, for almost all the examples drawn from our forefathers, and also many a word of theirs, are included within these three books; so that, although the language may not be graceful, yet a succession of old-time examples set down in such small compass may offer much instruction.
